title: Vectors: Motion along a curve part - c

content.description: A particle starts at point A on the positive x-axis at time t = 0 and travels along the curve from A to B to C to D, as shown above. The coordinates of the particle's position (x(t), y(t)) are differentiable functions of t, where <math> <semantics> <mrow> <msup> <mi>x</mi> <mo>′</mo> </msup> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mfrac> <mrow> <mi>d</mi> <mi>x</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mi>d</mi> <mi>t</mi> </mrow> </mfrac> <mo>=</mo> <mo>−</mo> <mn>9</mn> <mi>cos</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mrow> <mfrac> <mrow> <mi>π</mi> <mi>t</mi> </mrow> <mn>6</mn> </mfrac> </mrow> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mi>sin</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mrow> <mfrac> <mrow> <mi>π</mi> <msqrt> <mrow> <mi>t</mi> <mo>+</mo> <mn>1</mn> </mrow> </msqrt> </mrow> <mn>2</mn> </mfrac> </mrow> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@56F8@</annotation> </semantics> </math> and <math> <semantics> <mrow> <msup> <mi>y</mi> <mo>′</mo> </msup> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mfrac> <mrow> <mi>d</mi> <mi>y</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mi>d</mi> <mi>t</mi> </mrow> </mfrac> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@41E4@</annotation> </semantics> </math> is not explicitly given. At time t = 9, the particle reaches its final position at point D on the positive x-axis.
content.question: The line tangent to the curve at the point (x(8), y(8)) has equation <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>y</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mfrac> <mn>5</mn> <mn>9</mn> </mfrac> <mi>x</mi> <mo>−</mo> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3F96@</annotation> </semantics> </math>. Find the velocity vector and the speed of the particle at this point.

frqParts.text: The line tangent to the curve at the point (x(8), y(8)) has equation <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>y</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mfrac> <mn>5</mn> <mn>9</mn> </mfrac> <mi>x</mi> <mo>−</mo> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3F96@</annotation> </semantics> </math>. Find the velocity vector and the speed of the particle at this point.

unit.text: 9: Parametric Equations, Polar Coordinates, and Vector-Valued Functions

topic.text: 9.1: (BC ONLY) Defining and Differentiating Parametric Equations

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
